oclcdc:record.dc:title: The Prospect, December 1905, Volume 1, Number 2
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: essays; poems; campus news; advertisements; Plymouth Normal School; editorials; alumni news;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: The Prospect is a publication of Plymouth Normal School that consists of editorials, short stories, poetry, humor, campus news, and alumni updates. The last several pages of each issue contain advertisements for local businesses. The Prospect ran from 1905 to 1926, with a brief interruption during the years 1918 to 1920.

oclcdc:record.dc:title: Conning Tower Gleanings, Volume 2, Number 1, February 1952
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news; Plymouth Teachers College;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: Conning Tower Gleanings began in 1951 as a single page newsletter by the Plymouth Teachers College Alumni Association. This publication was superseded in 1982 by Plymouth Passages.

oclcdc:record.dc:title: Conning Tower Gleanings, Volume 1, Number 1, April 1951
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; Plymouth Teachers College;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: Conning Tower Gleanings began in 1951 as a single page newsletter by the Plymouth Teachers College Alumni Association. Over the years, articles grew in length and number, covering campus events, faculty profiles, and alumni news. Some issues also include enrollment figures. This publication was superseded in 1982 by Plymouth Passages.
oclcdc:record.dcterms:provenance: Michael J. Spinelli Jr. Center for University Archives and Special Collections, Plymouth State University, Plymouth, NH, USA
oclcdc:record.dc:description: CONNING TOWER GLEANINGS Vol. 1, No. 1 Plymouth, New Hampshire WE ARE HAVING A BIRTHDAY This year Plymouth Teachers College is celebrating its eightieth birthday. While we are not planning an elaborate birthday party, we should like to mark the occasion by honoring some of the graduates of the early days of Plymouth Normal School to whom we owe so much of our success. V/e hope that a good many of the fifty living graduates of the classes of 19J1 and preceding ones will be at the reunion luncheon. OUR CAMPUS IS GROV ING Our campus has changed considerably since the days of the Parsonage and Peppard House. Both of those buildings have been torn down; the former was replaced with lawn and the latter with the bridge of Hall Dormitory. The old Colley House, with the chicken yard gone, is now our attractive Administration Building. This last yea-r the third floor of Mary Lyon Hall was remodelled and 34 modern rooms were added. You will be interested in seeing these new rooms. OUR PROGRAM IS GROWING, TOO We now have four curricula: elementary, secondary in certain fields, early childhood, and business education. The early childhood program prepares teachers for nursery school and first and second grades. This is the only such curriculum offered north of Boston at the present time. To help meet the teacher shortage, we are offering a conversion program which enables liberal arts graduates and secondary teachers to qualify for elementary positions. This year we expect to award our first Master of Education degrees. Making graduate work available^ to teachers is another evidence that your college is keeping up to date and is trying to meet educational needs. SOME FACULTY MEMBERS HAVE LEFT US You may be interested in hearing about some of your favorite teachers who are no longer at Plymouth. Mr. Stevenson has retired. He lives in Plymouth and does some painting. Mr. Potlaid lives in Plymouth and is very active in the community. He is judge, secretary of the water department, and preacher. Mrs. Furlong is living in Georgia. Mjss Farrell is now married and is living in New York state. Miss McLane is living in Williamstown, Massachusetts. We hope that some of your former teachers will be here on May 12. THE ORGAN FUND NEEDS HELP A fund has been started to purchase an electric organ, which will be dedicated to Dr. Silver. This organ will be one that can be used in Livermore Hall and transferred to our new auditorium when we get it. REUNION DATE IS CHANGED Some of you felt that commencement time was not a good time for reunion. We want to make it as convenient as possible for you to come to the reunion. After all, that is your day. This year we are planning to have our annual get-together on Saturday, May 12. Our alumni luncheon will be separate from the students' so that we may visit to our hearts' content. The afternoon program will be in the form of a memory time. It will do you good to relive some of the activities of your school days at Plymouth, You will have a chance to hear our choir, too, and that in itself is worth coming for. In the evening the Social Club will present the Spring Formal. Members of the Alumni are invited to be guests. Dormitory accommodations will be available for botr. Friday and Saturday. You are cordially invited to be a guest of the College on either or both of these nights. Please let us know in advance if you plan to stay overnight.

oclcdc:record.dc:description: Conning Tower Gleanings began in 1951 as a single page newsletter by the Plymouth Teachers College Alumni Association. Over the years, articles grew in length and number, covering campus events, faculty profiles, and alumni news. Some issues also include enrollment figures. This publication was superseded in 1982 by Plymouth Passages. This issue contains a special report titled "1980!" which examines issues facing colleges and universities.
oclcdc:record.dc:creator: Plymouth State College Alumni Association
oclcdc:record.dcterms:provenance: Michael J. Spinelli Jr. Center for University Archives and Special Collections, Plymouth State University, Plymouth, NH, USA
oclcdc:record.dc:description: The text presented here is in raw, un-copyedited form, as created by optical character recognition (OCR) software. It is not always complete or accurate and should be used for preliminary research only.

oclcdc:record.dc:title: Plymouth Magazine, Volume 13, Number 2, Spring 1998
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: This publication replaced Plymouth State Update. Like the Update, each issue contains a column by the university president. Plymouth Magazine also has articles on Plymouth State's students, faculty, and staff, as well as shorter pieces on alumni news and campus events. From 1998-2004 the first issue in each volume includes the annual report of the college. Early issues contain a separately-numbered insert titled Alumni Green; starting with volume 17, Alumni Green is integrated into the regular pagination.
oclcdc:record.dc:creator: Plymouth State College Office of News Services

oclcdc:record.dc:description: PSC Notebook Spring Events Nearly 650 students received undergraduate degrees from Plymouth State College on May 16. More than 160 students earned master's and associate's degrees in separate ceremonies on May 9. One hundred and five awards were presented to PSC students during the annual Spring Convocation on May 15. Alumni Scholarships & Grants on Scholarship: ;humacher received the A i Cassella. Yicki Coodrie Recipier ts of the 1998 PSC Alumni iation Sehol: rships te, David Lambert and Anr a Peckham. Christ ith the 1998 Al mni Grants for Student Su are Jameson The Study of Snow PSC sen or Dennis Wilkens had a paper accepted for at the E sson Thee Regions Research and Engineering Milkens' paper grew sentatio i was titled "Rock Avalancl e, Cs nnon Cliffs, F rancor red by the U.S. Army Cold focused on the forecast- : at Plymouth. His pre- .valanche, Cannon Cliffs, Franconia Notch, N.H" Homework Online Two PSC students have developed a new software package that allows students of all ages to go online to get pursuing a degree in applied computer science, and Patrick Capone. who holds a degree in elementary education and is working toward his MBA at Plymouth. The new software is being marketed under the business name Better Education Through Technology (BETE). As of April, seven New I Iampshire schools and one in Indiana had already signed on. BETT hosts the program and all teacher pages on its own website so schools only need a computer with Internet access to use the system. DataStreme Project PSC is a mirror site and the primary backup site for the American Meteorological Society's (AMS) national DataStreme program web page and products. The DataStreme project involves K-12 teacher education programs focusing on meteorology. Currently, there are more than 600 teachers nationwide participating in the program, which includes out-of-class web-based assignments and research. Through the efforts of Jim Koermer, Archaeology Lab PSC has established an archaeology lab in the basement of Mary Lyon Hall for the purpose of cataloging and identifying artifacts and other found objects collected in field school classes. Personnel from the White Mountain National Forest will also use the facility for cleaning, conserving, cataloging and labeling anil acts. For more information, call Kate Donahue at 535-2424. Fond Farewell The college held an informal farewell for several of its most distinguished faculty and staff, who retired this spring. During the ceremony, PSC recognized Henry Vittum, Manuel Marquez-Sterling, Douglas Wiseman, Janet Nell, Russell Lord, Gerald Zinfon. S\ 1\ ia 1 lorgan. Philip Wei and Annette Carpenter for years of outstanding service to Plymouth State.

oclcdc:record.dc:description: Ut Prosibnm Notebook New Hampshire's Railroads R. Stuart Wallace of the Social Science Dept. was awarded a contract with the New Hampshire Department of Transportation to conduct a study of New I lampshire railroad history and to provide state and federal agencies with a context statement to help determine future use of suite railroad properties. Student Volunteer Recognition In a ceremony organized by PSC's Center for Community Enhancement, three PSC students were recognized by the organizations they served in and around the Plymouth community: Deana Trapani (Meredith Senior Center), Samantha Carpentiere (Plymouth Senior Center) and Karen Lord (Pemi-Bridge House). Mindflight '98 N Summer enrichment programs for middle school students, a school-year training and student enrichment program, and a residential summer institute for teachers were till part of this summer's Mindflight '98. The summer program for middle school students has grown from a single-theme academic day camp for 30 students from Plymouth area schools to the four-theme residential program that has been offered at PSC since 1996. During the first four years of Mindflight. more than 200 sixth, seventh and eighth grade students have participated. These programs are supported by PSC, grants from Bell Atlantic and by the Eisenhower Regional Alliance for Mathematics, Science and Technology Reform and Title I funds. For more information, call Jim McGarry of the Psychology Dept. at (603) 535-2365. Information is also available on the Internet at http ://mindflight. plymouth. edu/. Very Special Arts Art educators at Plymouth State coordinate two of the: a longstanding relationship with Very Special Arts Nev access to the arts for children and adults with disabilit program at PSC and Very Special Arts, after-school art Alternative Spring Break Two groups of PSC students volunteered to spend their Spring Break working on community service projects. One group served in soup kitchens in Washington, D.C. The other helped build a house with Habitat for four days working at a nursing home, an elementary school and a soup kitchen. Since then, groups have volunteered for projects in Philadelphia, Penn. and Battle Creek, Mich. Community Wellness Fairs PSC's Health Education Program sponsors free community wellness fairs and wellness forums in the Plymouth area during the academic year. The programs include seminars, exhibitions and free health screenings by Speare Memorial Hospital. For more information, call (603) 535-2515. Part-Time Police Academy PSC hosted the New- Hampshire Police Standards and Training Council's 206th Part tune Police Academy for eight weekends during the summer. The 206th Academy included nearly 50 students who received intensive training in many areas of law enforcement, such as constitutional law, criminal law, motor vehicle law, report writing and note taking, complaints and warrants, police ethics, civil liability, domestic violence and police defensive tactics, among other topics. Officers from PSC Security, Plymouth PD, Meredith PD, NH State Police, as well as PSC faculty, local attorneys and the Grafton County Attorney, served as instructors. PSC Security Sgts. oclcdc:record.dc:description: Sports Coaching changes abundant at PSC Coaching changes are a part of the landscape in the sports ivision III collegiate athletics. Plymouth State had been ft rfore it established itself as an athletic powerhouse, and it's only natural for coaches to ove on to bigger and better opportunities. But PSC has been hit hard in 1998, with new >aches expected in at least half of the sports at the home of the Panthers. "We recognize that PSC is a coaching cradle," says Athletic Director Steve Bamford. i in the eyes of any coach who wants to be successful in a head coaching role. But when our coaches have success here, they are going to be sought after by other schools who may be in a positi salary package. It's only natural that o changes at press time. s College after six years at PSC, Abby Burbank College, Burbank has been assistant women's lacrosse coach at William and Mary since 1994, and assistant field hockey coach since 1997. She earned a master's degree in Exercise and Sports Studies from Smith College in 1994, and had coaching stints at Smith College, Elms College and Amherst College. Following the resignation of women's soccer/women's basketball coach Marti Kingsley, PSC split the duties and hired two different individuals, a benefit to both the coaches and the student athletes. Bamford turned to the alumni ranks ft basketball. Field was a four-year starting sweeper and Ail-American for PSC, helping 1988-91. She also served four year assistant coach at PSC, as well as one year at Ft. Lewis College in Colorado. Lavigne two-sport standout during her days as an undergraduate (1991-94), earning All-S in both basketball and Softball. She also earned her master's degree in Sport Managem from PSC in 1996. and has spent the last two years as head women's basketball coach assistant athletic director at Endicott College. The Panther women's volleyball t< coaches in 1998. John Garneau, '64, wh< remarkable 47-13 record in its first two seasons, retired from coaching to spend n with his family. He was replaced by Mariann Hunter, who had been C natural successor. Unfortunately for PSC, Hunter relinquished the positi coached a match. Her new position in College Ad prevented her from becoming PSC's volleyball coa left the Panthers searching for another Spaulding High School in Rochester. The Panther men's basketball coach for the past eight years, Hogan was a e Coach of the Year and stepped aside with the highest winning percentage (.630) in the history of the program, posting a 136- guided PSC to five post- years, including the school's only NCAA berth in 1996.

In this issue we look at the teach ng life at PSC: from an array of s udent teaching experiences, to our distin guished teachers on what makes teaching distinguished, from spotlights on some of our graduates who are being re warded as educators, to our summer educati onal programs and our new post master's Certificate of Advanced Gradual e Studies. "She's constantly feeding me infon If she finds any article or hook on a subject she kno' icks and huaraches, I rences to Elvis, Star \ :, Mad IV ratelul I indent shamanistie rituals between the cave paintings of I.aseaux and the idle doodling of a college student, between trance states in Tanz nia and the mysterious force of Jedi warriors, Donahue helps her students find a connection between their own lives and those of people in other cultures and other "Eric Severeid said something like, 'In this world we all very alike and also all very different,'" says Donahue. "This seems like a good thing to know in this world." Climbing on a chair, Donahue observes. "Almost evt culture has a rising water myth. They have an origin anc creation myth." Holding up an eraser, Donahue talks about cargo cu and ghost dance, ethnomusicology and rites of intensific tion. It's hard not to be mesmerized by the breadth of th material. "Beware of people trying to offer you a better life," she says of cults. "You can argue with me about an whoc s why we need people like Mil Donahue plays a tape of sounds from the rain forest at the same time she shows slides of the "emerald door' Students listen to insects, howler monkeys, various animal murmuring, even a jaguar. Donahue reads from Tales of a Shaman Apprentice, by Mark Plotkin. They discuss witch doctors and curses, out-of-body experiences and medicinal plants. One student, who has researched the Yanomamo. speaks passionately about the dying of their culture. Deforestation, modern diseases and other factors are contributing to the demise of a whole way of life. A somber silence descends. "Are there any cultures left intact, free from modern influ- "It can get depressing," she says later. "We're destroying the world. The theme of the cultural ecology class is that native people have knowledge that can be useful to westerners. It needs to be understood before it disappears." oclcdc:record.dc:description: A step beyond the master's: CAGS and educational leadership Say you're a high school administrator with a desin itinselor at a college who has alw s. How eof ii while managing a full work schedule? The Certificate of Advanced Graduate Studies at Plymouth State is a post master's program, sponsored by PSC and the New Hampshire State Department of Education, designed for persons interested in pursuing advanced academic work in educational change and leadership. Now in its second year at PSC, the CAGS program graduated its first lour students in May,(Gail Carr and Stephen Lambert, PSC's coordinator of continuing education and director of career development, respectively; Kathleen Norris and Barbara Cohen), established a doctoral program option in collaboration with the University of Sarasota, and garnered rave reviews from its participants, all of whom are mid-career professionals with full-time jobs in education or human service-related fields. What makes Plymouth's program unique, besides its strong focus on leadership and its exchange with Sarasota, is its implementation of cohort groups, small groups that take classes together, similar to a college class. "The nature of PSC's CAGS program, built around a cohort group, made it special for me," says Kathleen Norris, director of guidance at Plymouth Regional High School, a CAGS graduate currently pursuing her doctorate through community Detween people. We worked together, discussed ideas, proofread each others' papers, helped each other get S program d whoii dthe head of school at New Hampton School, and a CAGS student. This year, Roland Bixby, a student in my junior English class there, called and hadn ;n him for 50 years, though I was only 17 when I last saw minded me that I had been 21! 1 to believe it, but he told me he best teacher he had ever d become a college teacher, has e books, and is now retired. at he or she has made a lasting it otherwise?" With Lindbergh's help, Hatab self-designed a degree program that he describes as a forerunner of the Integrated Arts option adopted at PSC in 1996. "In elementary school we need connectivity." Hatab explains. "We need to integrate and blend things. We use music, dance, drama, painting the whether Johnny can draw. There's plenty of room in the curriculum for movement and dance and music...not just the visual arts." Hatab has received a grant for an arts in education development project to design a Higher Order Thinking (HOT) program at Beaver Meadow in Concord. Gilford, where he taught for 1 t years, has a similar program. HOT Schools are arts-infused, arts-enriched schools that use learning in, about, and through the arts as a key pathway to developing higher order thinking "It's a model for how we want our kids to learn,'' according to Hatab. "We want them to learn to think and to solve problems. We want them to know how to take in information, synthesize it, and churn it out in a completed form. This is just what the artist does." oclcdc:record.dc:title: Plymouth Magazine, Volume 13, Number 3, Autumn 1998
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: This publication replaced Plymouth State Update. Like the Update, each issue contains a column by the university president. Plymouth Magazine also has articles on Plymouth State's students, faculty, and staff, as well as shorter pieces on alumni news and campus events. From 1998-2004 the first issue in each volume includes the annual report of the college. Early issues contain a separately-numbered insert titled Alumni Green; starting with volume 17, Alumni Green is integrated into the regular pagination.

oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: This publication replaced Plymouth State Update. Like the Update, each issue contains a column by the university president. Plymouth Magazine also has articles on Plymouth State's students, faculty, and staff, as well as shorter pieces on alumni news and campus events. From 1998-2004 the first issue in each volume includes the annual report of the college. Early issues contain a separately-numbered insert titled Alumni Green; starting with volume 17, Alumni Green is integrated into the regular pagination.
oclcdc:record.dc:creator: Plymouth State University Office of Public Relations
oclcdc:record.dcterms:provenance: Michael J. Spinelli Jr. Center for University Archives and Special Collections, Plymouth State University, Plymouth, NH, USA
oclcdc:record.dc:description: The text presented here is in raw, un-copyedited form, as created by optical character recognition (OCR) software. It is not always complete or accurate and should be used for preliminary research only.

oclcdc:record.dc:title: Plymouth Passages, Fall 1982
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news; Plymouth State College;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: This publication by the Plymouth State College Alumni Association superseded Conning Tower Gleanings and is continued by Plymouth State Update after 1985. In addition to alumni news, Plymouth Passages reports on campus events, Plymouth State sports teams, and faculty news.
oclcdc:record.dc:creator: Plymouth State College Alumni Association
oclcdc:record.dcterms:provenance: Michael J. Spinelli Jr. Center for University Archives and Special Collections, Plymouth State University, Plymouth, NH, USA

oclcdc:record.dc:title: Conning Tower Gleanings, Winter 1976
oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news; Plymouth State College;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: Conning Tower Gleanings began in 1951 as a single page newsletter by the Plymouth Teachers College Alumni Association. Over the years, articles grew in length and number, covering campus events, faculty profiles, and alumni news. Some issues also include enrollment figures. This publication was superseded in 1982 by Plymouth Passages.
oclcdc:record.dc:creator: Plymouth State College Alumni Association
oclcdc:record.dcterms:provenance: Michael J. Spinelli Jr. Center for University Archives and Special Collections, Plymouth State University, Plymouth, NH, USA
oclcdc:record.dc:description: The text presented here is in raw, un-copyedited form, as created by optical character recognition (OCR) software. It is not always complete or accurate and should be used for preliminary research only.

oclcdc:record.dc:subject: campus news; alumni news; Plymouth State College;
oclcdc:record.dc:description: Running from 1985-1997, the Plymouth State Update contains feature articles on faculty research, campus events, and a column by the president of the college. oclcdc:record.dc:title: New Hampshire, Volume 3, Number 2, October 1974
oclcdc:record.dc:source: New Hampshire: The Magazine of the University System
oclcdc:record.dc:description: New Hampshire: The Magazine of the University System was the printed voice for the University System of New Hampshire, including UNH, Plymouth State, Keene State, and Merrimack. All four campuses contributed articles on major campus events, projects, and programs. After Volume 7 in 1972, the enumeration starts over at Volume 1 in 1973. This New Hampshire is unrelated to the commercial publication of the same name.

oclcdc:record.dc:description: The Prospect is a publication of Plymouth Normal School that consists of editorials, short stories, poetry, humor, campus news, and alumni updates. editor
